title: Production on CBS’s ‘Training Day’ Starring Bill Paxton Had Already Been Completed
text: Bill Paxton had completed work on CBS drama Training Day before his untimely death. Paxton died after suffering complications from surgery. He was 61. His passing leaves the CBS reboot as his last TV role. Production on the midseason drama was completed in December. Four of the show’s 13 episodes have already aired on CBS. Read more: Bill Paxton, ‘Aliens’ and 'Twister’ Actor, Dies at 61 Described as a reimagining of the Antoine Fuqua feature film of the same name, the CBS series begins 15 years after the 2001 movie left off. It centers on an idealistic young African-American police officer (Justin Cornwell) who is appointed to an elite squad of the LAPD where he is partnered with a seasoned, morally ambiguous detective ( Bill Paxton ). Will Beall created the series and exec produces alongside Jerry Bruckheimer, Jonathan Littman, KristieAnne Reed, Fuqua; Danny Cannon and showrunner Barry Schindel. “We are truly devastated at the passing of our friend Bill Paxton,” Bruckheimer said in a statement Sunday. "He was a tremendously talented actor, and a wonderful man beloved by the entire Training Day cast and crew. Bill’s extraordinary body of work ensures that he will never be forgotten. Our heartfelt condolences to Bill’s family and friends. He will be missed more than we can possibly express.“ Cornwell paid tribute to his co-star on Twitter early Sunday: We were just two guys on top of the world. Rest easy my friend pic.twitter.com/R0ZwB0zv5q - Justin Cornwell (@justin_cornwell) February 26, 2017 The series debuted Feb. 2 to lackluster ratings and has dipped in the three weeks since its premiere. Training Day was not expected to be renewed and Paxton’s untimely passing makes a second season now increasingly unlikely.
